content.text: Measure and record the diameter \(d\) of the short sample of wire that is attached to the card. You may remove the wire from the card
Calculate the cross-sectional area \(A\) of the wire, in \(\text{m}^2\), using the formula
Using the wire attached to the metre rule, set up the circuit shown in Fig. 1.1
There are two crocodile clips labelled P and Q
Position the slider approximately half-way along the rheostat (variable resistor)
Attach Q approximately half-way along the wire
Switch on the power supply
Measure and record the length \(l\) of wire between P and Q
Record the voltmeter reading \(V.\)
Record the ammeter reading \(I.\)
Switch off the power supply
Reposition Q at a new distance \(l\) from P
Switch on the power supply
Adjust the slider on the rheostat until the ammeter reading is the same value as in (b)(vi)
Measure and record the length \(l\) of wire between P and Q
Record the voltmeter reading \(V.\)
Switch off the power supply
Repeat **(c)** until you have six sets of readings of \(l\) and \(V.\)
For each value of \(l\), adjust the slider on the rheostat so that the ammeter reading \(I\) remains constant at the value in (b)(vi)
You may find it helpful to copy your value from **(b)(vi)** here
Include values of \(\frac{V}{l}\) and \(\frac{1}{l}\) in your table
Plot a graph of \(\frac{V}{l}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(\frac{1}{l}\) on the \(x\)-axis
Draw the straight line of best fit
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line
gradient =
Use your answers in **(e)(iii)** to determine values for \(M\) and \(N\)
The resistivity \(\rho\) of the material of the wire, in \(\Omega \text{m}\), can be found using the relationship
Using your answers in **(a)(ii)**, **(b)(vi)** and **(f)(i)**, calculate a value for \(\rho\)
The quantities \(V\) and \(l\) are related by the equation
where \(M\) and \(N\) are constants
In this experiment, you will determine the resistivity of a metal in the form of a wire
Set up the two runways as shown in Fig. 2.1
One end of each runway should be resting on the bench. The other end should be clamped firmly at a height \(H\) approximately \(15 \text{cm}\) above the bench
The runways should be lined up so that a ball rolling down one would roll up the other
Measure and record \(H\)
Place the ball close to the top of one of the runways as shown in Fig. 2.2
Fig. 2.2
Measure and record the height \(h_{1}\) of the bottom of the ball above the bench
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(h_{1}\)
percentage uncertainty =   .........
Place the ball on the runway at the height given in **(b)**(ii)
Release the ball
The ball should roll down one runway and up the other one, as shown in Fig. 2.3
Fig. 2.3
Measure and record the maximum height \(h_{2}\) of the bottom of the ball above the bench
Calculate the fractional loss of energy \(F\), where
Place the ball at a lower starting position so that the height \(h_{1}\) is approximately half the value in (b)(ii)
Repeat (b)(ii), (c)(ii), (c)(iii) and (d)

where \(k\) is a constant
Describe four sources of uncertainty or limitations of the procedure for this experiment
Describe four improvements that could be made to this experiment. You may suggest the use of other apparatus or different procedures
You may not need to use all of the materials provided
In this experiment, you will investigate how the loss of gravitational potential energy of a rolling ball depends on its initial height
